summary:
Kim Dokja gets de-aged as a result of a mishap with an artifact, post-epilogue. Uncomfortable truths come out.

(Or, they love Kim Dokja, no matter what form he’s taken.

 

He doesn’t know what to do with this much love.)

...

When he wakes up again, it’s to a whole group of people, most of which are noisy and loud.

He lies there in the soft blanket for a minute, taking in the details of a hospital room, and noting the IV going into the crook of his elbow. He attempts to sit up, wincing when it pulls at the mess of his chest.

There’s an odd weight on one of his legs, and there’s a fluffy...creature resting on it, curled into his side. It’s warm.

The room goes quiet all of a sudden, and he finds himself staring back at an odd assortment of people.

Yoo Jonghyuk’s eyes are piercing. They burn through him, straight through his paper-thin defenses and whatever doors he’d managed to put up to keep himself away from the thoughts that had led him to try his luck in the afterlife.

Reader Kim, Lonely Child Kim, only fit to suffer and die before he causes more pain for others.

When they exit the subway, both adults turn and watch the doors close and the train leave, peering through the windows as if making sure nothing was left behind. They look him over once too, as if afraid they left a piece of him behind as well.

He’s been regaining his memories piece by piece—not enough to form a clear picture on anything but enough to attain an echo, a shadow, a vague afterimage of who he had been (will be).

Dokja remembers the feel of Unbroken Faith in his hands, how it feels to die, and watching Yoo Jonghyuk (unscarred and almost hopeful) from the windows of a subway car, but he has no context for it, no timeline.

Trading fingers for Yoo Jonghyuk’s happiness, wings sprouting from his back, the strange sensation of turning into a ghost, his fingers turning into wisps of smoke in a tunnel.

“Omniscient Reader?” he reads aloud, uncertain. “Interesting name for a novel.”

“You’ve read it before,” she says, eyes shining. “But I think you’ll enjoy it.”

He flips it open, and reads the first lines.

text:
Kim Dokja wakes up in the hospital at age fifteen after jumping off a roof and finds a woman staring down at him sadly, her hands brushing through his hair gently. 
It’s not his mother, but someone who moves gracefully and slowly, movements refined and elegant.
He must be dreaming, he thinks. He must say something out loud because the woman smiles sadly and brushes her thumb over his cheek.
“This is real, little one,” she hums. Her voice has an odd sing-song quality to it. There’s a man hovering over her shoulder, quiet and imposing.
“He’s so small at this age,” she whispers to him. The man nods silently.
He finds himself falling back asleep. The last thing he hears before he goes to a dreamless sleep is her quiet voice.
“I wish we could have helped, little heir.”
When he wakes up again, it’s to a whole group of people, most of which are noisy and loud.
He lies there in the soft blanket for a minute, taking in the details of a hospital room, and noting the IV going into the crook of his elbow. He attempts to sit up, wincing when it pulls at the mess of his chest. 
There’s an odd weight on one of his legs, and there’s a fluffy...creature resting on it, curled into his side. It’s warm. 
The room goes quiet all of a sudden, and he finds himself staring back at an odd assortment of people—two kids, a teenager sitting with them, a broad-shouldered man with a kind face, a pretty woman with brown hair with a woman polishing a sword, one with short black hair and a beauty mark, and a man with gold eyes like nothing he’s ever seen before and scars peeking out from everywhere. 
Everyone stares, and he stares back at them, eyes wide. He fights the urge to shrink back under the blankets. 
He must be dreaming, or they must have the wrong room.
One of them says, “He’s so cute as a kid,” while another one mutters “How’d he get those injuries anyway?”
Neither of those statements makes sense. 
There’s a moment of silence before he speaks, unwilling to let these people sit with the wrong person for another moment. How did they end up in his room anyway? He looks out the window for a moment to gather his words, but stops abruptly.
This doesn’t look quite like Seoul.
“Where...where am I?” it comes out soft, his voice hoarse from disuse.
One of the two kids—a sweet looking girl—tilts her head. “Ahjussi, what do you mean?”
He really must be dreaming, he thinks, as he points to himself and mouths ‘Ahjussi.’ He’s clearly a kid. He looks down at his hands—they are small, and just as he remembers (weak and no good at stopping the bullies.)
“I think you have the wrong room,” he says haltingly, confused. “I’m Kim Dokja. I’m fifteen, I go to Seoul High School...”
The room goes deathly quiet again, and the woman polishing her sword gets this scary glint in her eye.
The teenager growls. “I’m really going to put my sword through whichever stupid part of Star Stream decided this would be a good idea. You’d think, once we reached the end, the bullshit would be over.”
Sword? Star Stream? Is he in a room full of Chuunis?
“Star Stream…?”
The scarred man, who is unfairly good looking (protagonist, his mind whispers) looks angry. He storms out of the room, slamming the door shut behind him.
The rest of the group looks rather worried, and scared.
The young boy starts to say “You really don’t remember anything…”
No, he doesn’t, not beyond the roof and free-falling, and he really, really, doesn’t want to mention that. Is this the afterlife? Did he succeed in dying after all? Did he end up in hell? 
(Hell wouldn’t have people that look this kind. But it could have Kim Dokja.)
The woman with the brown hair must sense that he’s getting agitated, because she quickly comes over and sits on the bed by his legs. Her face does something complicated when she sees his hands gripping tightly at the blanket, before it smooths out and she runs a hand through his hair.
He looks up at her, mystified by her touch.
“I’m Yoo Sangah,” she tells him, slowly taking one of his hands. “What do you remember?”
...
It turns out he got thrown more than a decade into the future, and managed to miss the apocalypse. Or, at least, his current self did. His real self, the one who lived through the end of the world, had apparently run into one of the last remaining artifacts and been reverted back to a child—of course, he thinks, that his future self would have the same bad luck.
Apparently, this means he survives past 30.
(He thought he was done for at 15, so this is a bit of a shock.)
They’d thought he’d just physically (not mentally) become younger, unaware that he’d been totally swapped out for 15-year-old Kim Dokja. Hence the little girl calling him Ahjussi.
Yoo Sangah had dropped the fluffy creature thing into his hands and he held onto its warmth while it nudged him roughly, yelling “Ba-at! Ba-aht!”
Apparently her name is Biyoo, and she turns into a human. He finds this out when she disappears in a puff of smoke and there’s a girl standing in her place.
Yoo Sangah laughs at the face he makes.
When he wakes up again, he finds Biyoo in human form curled into his side this time, carefully avoiding all his injuries. She sleepily blinks open her eyes when he shifts, watching him as he groggily finds the land of the living again. She shifts so that her face presses into his neck, and he freezes at the sudden contact. Her hand winds around his.
“Sleep,” she says softly, with a voice somehow weighted by a thousand years. He sleeps, warm and held.
The kid looks so small, and his eyes are empty—the bandages that wind around his body peak out from under the oversized sweater they’d found for him.
They decide to give him some space so they don’t overwhelm him with years worth of friendship and trust and far too many deaths, making it so that he’s never alone but that there aren’t more than two or three of them with him.
It’s painful, seeing him this way—it’s too painfully close to the ‘Most Ancient Dream’. It’s painful to see him young and unsure, watching them warily like he’s uncertain of when they’ll turn on him.
“I don’t know why they left you with me,” the lady with the beauty mark says. “I’m horrible with kids.”
He immediately feels bad—he doesn’t want to make trouble for her.
(She sounds a bit like his relatives, arguing over having to take him in. Will she leave him too? Does she hate him?)
She must see something in his face, because she closes the book in her lap immediately and sighs, coming closer till she sits on the side of his bed. She ruffles his hair gently, taking care to avoid the bandages. 
“Do you like stories?” she asks.
He nods quietly. Escape, they’re an escape.
She chuckles softly, and he thinks she mutters something that sounds like “of course you do.” He doesn’t know why she would know that.
She flips open the book in her hands again, filled with pages of handwriting he thinks might be hers.
She confirms it when she holds it out in front of him and says, “Want to read my new novel? It’s a work in progress right now, and my current editor is—“ she pauses for a moment, expression going unreadable—“unavailable. Why don’t you tell me what you think instead?”
He carefully takes the book from her hands and opens it. She smiles widely, pulling a lemon candy from her pocket and giving it to him as well. 
The two kids—Shin Yoosoung and Lee Gilyoung—play card games with him and laugh when he loses, but it isn’t mocking. Lee Gilyoung shows him his grasshopper collection and Shin Yoosoung tells him grasshoppers are ugly and then they start squabbling, only stopped from physically shoving each other by Kim Dokja’s legs in between them from where they’re sitting on either side of him on the bed.
Lee Jihye—the teenager who’d mentioned swords and the Star Stream—she shoos them out when they get rowdy, telling them off for not being careful. He’s still healing, she says, don’t jostle him unnecessarily.
The kids immediately look contrite.
She sighs, rubbing her temples.
“Why don't you both go bother Heewon—sshi,” she mutters. “You can get her to decide whether grasshoppers are ugly or not.”
The kids reluctantly leave the hospital room, squeezing his hands before they go, and their arguing echoes down the hall as they go.
“Guess you’re stuck with me now, squid.”
“Squid…?”
She grins evilly, and he gets the feeling he’s being made fun of but he doesn’t know how.
His injuries ache sometimes—they don’t ask him how he got them, just hold his hands when he pulls at the still healing ruin of his skin, gently pull him to his feet when he’s deemed fit enough to walk. 
The broad shouldered man, Lee Hyungsung, is there a lot when he wakes up. (It’s never the scarred man with the gold eyes.)
He’s usually asleep in the uncomfortable hospital chairs, muttering in his sleep about cartridges and lost bullets. He’s almost like a bodyguard.
He smiles when he’s awake at the same time as Kim Dokja, and tells him rambling stories with too many military based metaphors that he doesn’t mind hearing anyway.
The doctor-lady—she’s said her name was Aileen—looks him over once more and tells him he can leave the room and stay with his family.
She’d called them his family.
(If he thinks about it too hard he’ll start to cry.)
She puts her hands on her shoulders and suddenly glares at him. “If you get injured again,” she growls threateningly, “You are going to be in so much trouble. I’ve had to patch you up enough times over the years. It’s like you’ve never heard the words ‘self-preservation’ before. If it hurts too bad, or you feel worse, you let them know and you come straight. back. here. Understood?”
He nods, a little frightened.
She smiles widely, as if she hadn’t threatened him a second ago, mussing his hair.
They take him to a house, and it’s so lived in and warm that his head spins. All of them live in the same one, and it feels so alive compared to the empty, impersonal hospital room.
They give him his future self’s bedroom, but then they all pile in it anyway, the floor a mosaic of sleeping bags and futons they’ve scrounged up. He knows they were giving him space, but apparently that rule doesn’t apply at night. 
In the morning, a woman with bright orange-gold hair slams into him when he wakes up, squishing his cheeks.
“You’re so cute,” she coos, holding his face. “I’m going to keep you, no matter what Yoo Jonghyuk says.”
“Uriel,” someone calls.
“Yes, my lovely incarnation?”
“You’re going to suffocate him.”
“I am not!”
She definitely is.
 
Jung Heewon pries the woman off of him with a long suffering sigh. 
 
 
The brooding man is in the kitchen when he wanders in, wondering if he can quickly grab something so he doesn’t have to trouble Sangah noona (she’d gone a little misty-eyed when he’d called her noona for the first time, while Uriel pouted behind her.)The man goes still when he sees Kim Dokja, knife midway through cutting an onion. Kim Dokja freezes too, unsure of what to do. The man looked so angry earlier, in the hospital room. He knows that angry people can be violent, can hurt you.
 
(And you can hurt them back but in the end in only ever hurts you more—)
The man sets the knife down and silently strides towards him, sticking out like a sore thumb in the pristine nearly all-white kitchen in his all-black clothes. He looks like a protagonist. Dokja feels like he should be afraid—instead he just feels a sense of calm, like he’s safe. He tilts his head upwards so he can make eye contact with the tall man, see what he’ll do.
The man just continues to tower over him, quietly observing. They stand like that for a half-minute, watching each other, before the tall man kneels down and stares him in the eyes. Dokja isn’t sure what he’s looking for. He reaches towards Kim Dokja’s hands, which are twisted in his sweater, and rolls up the sleeves so he can see the bandages that wind up the length of his arms. It stings a little bit, but he doesn’t let that show on his face. 
Satisfied by whatever he saw, the man stares at him again. If he didn’t know any better, he’d say the man looked sad for a moment. 
“Watch,” he rumbles, voice deep yet soft. He continues to dice the onions, then stirs whatever is in the pot that smells fantastic. Dragging a stool over from the dining area, he sets it in front of the stove and then, to Dokja’s surprise, lifts Kim Dokja on top of it, like he weighs nothing.
“Stir,” he orders quietly. “Earn your dinner.”
It’s relaxing, watching him cut and dice and taste while stirring the pot and occasionally doing whatever other tasks he is asked to do.
A half hour later, a rather harried looking Uriel and Lee Jihye skid into the kitchen.
“Have you seen—“
“We’ve been looking all over—“
They both abruptly stop when they see Dokja hovering over the stove.
There’s a pause before both of them squeal. Uriel takes out her phone and takes a picture before him or the man can relax.
Jihye laughs. “I’m definitely telling Ahjussi about this when he returns, ” she snorts. “The great Yoo Jonghyuk, giving ahjus—a kid cooking lessons.”
Yoo Jognhyuk. That must be the mans name. It’s almost familiar. It sounds right, correct, like any other name would have been a mistake, a false moniker.
Yoo Jonghyuk nods at the vegetables he’s managed to messily dice, ignoring the two woman, who have begun crying while holding each other. “Good job,” he says, and for a second Dokja can feel a hand on his hair before it disappears. 
Dinner that night tastes wonderful. Yoo Jonghyuk glares at him until he takes seconds, Lee Hyungsung telling him he’s too light.
“Good soldiers need to have more meat on their bones,” he says, looking rather stressed.
“Hyungsung-sshi, he’s not a soldier though. He’s fifteen.”
 
“It’s never too early to start preparing!”
 
“Were you born in a military uniform?”
 
“...No?”
 
“With a gun?”
 
“No, Sooyoung—sshi.”
 
Han Sooyoung leans over to whisper in his ear. “He totally was,” she says gleefully. “I bet he came out of the womb talking about bullets and manuals and cartridges.”
Dokja laughs, and Sooyoung noona smiles at him before cackling.
 
Lee Hyungsung puts his head in his hands.
Sometimes it feels like he’s struggling to fill a hole left by someone so much bigger and ingrained in these people's lives—they’ll slip up sometimes, reference a memory he doesn’t have, a joke he doesn’t have the context for.
They love the old him so much, it’s painful. He wonders what he did to deserve such unconditional, burning love.
He hears Yoo Sangah talking to someone at night, their voice so familiar but he can’t quite tell if it’s the one he’s thinking of, who should be behind prison bars.
“He’s alright,” Yoo Sangah says to the person just outside the door. They never come inside, but he does hear them stand by the entrance for a few minutes, quietly breathing.
He never turns around to look at them, because he doesn’t know what ugly thing he’ll do if he’s right and he’s correct about the person who visits every once in a while but never where he can see them.
It’d be too painful for them both.
They have a steady stream of visitors—a white-haired lady who shakes her head when she sees his bandages and redoes them. Her name is Lee Seolhwa.
An energetic blond girl, Jang Hayoung, who gives him dumplings and laughs when his eyes go wide at the delicious taste.
Gong Pildu, an old man who takes one look at him and scoffs. “To think, you’re like a twig. Some constellation,” he snaps. 
Another man, with a daughter, who nearly faints when he claps eyes on Kim Dokja. “You should think about working for Minosoft,” he suggests. “When you graduate. I bet you’ll get a wonderful department head—“
Yoo Sangah hits him over the head with a book and smiles dangerously at him.
Han Myongoh swallows the rest of his words.
He thinks about the words later at night, listening to the deepening breathing of the people sleeping (or snoring, in the case of Lee Hyungsung) around him.
“When you graduate.”
Is he going to be stuck in the body forever, a time traveler out of place? He wants his original body, he wants to be the person these people love, he wants it so badly that it aches. He doesn’t want to be the lonely boy who jumped off the roof who’s too scared to tell this family that he was so alone that he wanted to die. 
He finds himself on the roof again—oh, the irony—but someone else is there too.
“I thought they’d do a better job of watching you when you’re a child,” Yoo Jonghyuk mutters. “But you’ve always been a pain in the neck, hmm?”
He stares back silently, unsure of what to say.
“What are you doing here," the man asks quietly. He follows it up with something that sounds a lot like ‘rat bastard’ but it’s too quiet for Dokja to make out.
He opens his mouth to try to answer the question.
Yoo Jonghyuk’s eyes are piercing. They burn through him, straight through his paper-thin defenses and whatever doors he’d managed to put up to keep himself away from the thoughts that had led him to try his luck in the afterlife.
Reader Kim, Lonely Child Kim, only fit to suffer and die before he causes more pain for others.
That doesn’t match up with the life his older self has here, doesn’t match up with his carefully constructed barriers and self-imposed apathy, doesn’t line up with being so fundamentally unloved. 
Reader Kim, somehow so broken by his mother's stories that she’d written (to save him, to save him, oh the irony it is so cruel.)
He opens his mouth to try to answer again, only to find that the words don’t come and he’s crying, tears leaving little dark spots on the concrete of the roof. He does it silently, the figure of Yoo Jonghyuk blurring before him.
The great imposing mass of black (he hasn’t seen him wear anything but black, how strange) kneels before him.
“Dokja.”
He keeps his gaze on the floor, watching his tears soak into the ground.
“Dokja, look up.”
The voice is commanding, and he doesn’t want to make Yoo hyung mad, so he tilts his head up so they’re looking each other in the eyes again, like in the kitchen.
“They love you,” Yoo hyung says, and it’s so at odds with the earlier command that he takes in a sharp breath.
“They love you. This isn’t a dream.” The sentences are short, clipped. They can’t be real.
“They really do love you, idiot. And I love you too. And so does, believe it or not, this sunfish over here.” Dokja whips his head around to see Han Sooyoung leaning on the doorframe, grinning wickedly. Out of the corner of his eye, he sees Yoo Jonghyuk nod at her.
“Don’t try to leave,” she says, waving around her lollipop. “They’ll lose their minds. And if you die again, well. I’ll lose my mind too.” The smile has dropped off her face entirely. She looks dangerous, backlit from the light behind the dirt, shadows twisting across her face.
He hears the sound of Yoo Jonghyuk’s clothes rustling as he stands up, sees the longer shadow he casts, then feels a soft pressure on the back of his neck. There are fingers there, gently holding him in place. The walk back off of the roof is a blank space in his mind—only the feel of Yoo hyung’s fingers keep him tethered.
They don’t take him to the room where everyone is sleeping, instead leading him to another one that he thinks might be Han Sooyoung’s—there are papers scattered everywhere, and a cluttered desk filled with pens, an open laptop with the screen dark. He’s maneuvered into sitting on the bed. He winces when it pulls at something under the few remaining bandages.
“How did you get these injuries?” Sooyoung noona asks casually, deliberately making it seem like an offhand question.
Again, he opens his mouth and nothing comes out. They watch him closely, Yoo Jonghyuk’s fingers pressing on the back of his neck and Han Sooyoung crouching in front of him.
“I fell,” he manages, because he doesn’t want to tell them that he jumped off the roof himself, but he says it too fast and with a shaking voice.
Yoo Jonghyuk says nothing, just continues to watch him with those eyes that seem to see right through him.
Han Sooyoung also watches him like she knows every thought he’s ever had. 
He wouldn’t call them affectionate like Yoo Sangah or Lee Hyunsung, or the kids, but he would still call them kind, and caring, and people he is so wholly undeserving of.
They don’t pull away when he starts crying again, unable to stop the tears from coming. They don’t leave, just look knowing and resigned and angry, but not at him. 
“I jumped,” he half-chokes out, and the grip on the back of his neck momentarily stiffens, before going lax. The pressure goes away, and suddenly there are fingers gently wiping away his tears. Jonghyuk doesn’t look at him directly as he does it, instead making eye contact with Sooyoung noona, who’s sitting on the floor with her knees folded up to her chest, watching them both.
He feels tired, all of a sudden, like the admission took something out of him. He leans into Yoo hyung’s space, then buries his head into the (very hard) chest, throwing his arms around his torso. He feels him go stiff with shock or surprise, and hears the soft gasp from Han Sooyoung. There’s a moment of stillness, before fingers card through his hair and then he’s pulled down so he’s lying on the bed. 
He loosens his hold on Yoo Jonghyuk, certain they’re going to leave him here to sleep. Instead, the mattress dips a bit as the man lies down next to him, and then creaks as Han Sooyoung joins.
Sandwiched between them, his tears slow down until he’s just hiccuping slightly, curling into their bodies. 
“Don’t do it again,” Han Sooyoung whispers, pushing his hair out of his eyes. “You have things worth living for. Your father hurt you, I know—“
His eyes snap up to hers, because how could she know about the bruises and the knife and his mother wilting—
 
His future self must have told them. 
“But you overcame it all, Kim Dokja. Don’t let these ghosts haunt you anymore.”
Yoo Jonghyuk shifts so that there’s a gentle press of fingers to his neck again.
They fall asleep together, Han Sooyoung and Yoo Jonghyuk on either side of him, arms thrown across him like they’d never let him go.
In the morning, he wakes up to see Uriel watching them sleep. It looks like she’s crying, and she has her phone out again. Yoo Jonghyuk wakes up when the camera shutter goes off, pulling out an entire sword (from where?) and pointing it at her, eyes narrowed and practically glowing with anger. 
“This is going to be my lock screen,” Uriel sobs, and shoves Yoo Jonghyuk aside so she can hug (suffocate) Dokja again, pushing Han Sooyoung off the bed in the process.
The commotion causes the rest of the house to wake up, and there’s brief panic where the occupants of the other room realize they lost Kim Dokja and then find him in Uriel’s arms.
 
(Jung Heewon extracts him from her grip again.)
The next day, he finds Han Sooyoung at the laptop he’d seen earlier, holding a manuscript with tons of markings in red ink. The markings look similar to his own handwriting, and he puts the pieces together.
“Was I your editor, Sooyoung noona?”
She looks startled at the usage of the honorific, and even more so once she manages to piece together what he’s said.
“Yeah, yeah you were. You leave the most annoying comments, you know?”
Her face goes downright murderous. “Even your comments on Ways of Survival—“
She cuts herself off abruptly. Strangely, she grabs him by the shoulders and looks him dead in the eyes. (A lot of people have been doing this lately, haven’t they? Like they wish they could drill lessons into his head.)
(Self-preservation, Aileen had said.)
“Keep writing your comments, ok? Sure, they’re annoying as fuck—“
There’s a yell from the room across the hall that sounds like Yoo Sangah saying “Language!”
“—but don’t stop. You love stories, don’t you?”
She looks a little desperate, a little manic, so he nods. And he does love stories.
 
For some reason, they all avoid the subway. They take him for grocery shopping but they never use the subway, either getting in a car or walking. They act like there are ghosts at the station.

Dokja doesn’t say anything about the way they all lean slightly towards him, with glances that they must think are hidden, as if he’ll fall over any minute.
Sooyoung must have told the others his memory was returning, because they don’t look surprised when he croaks out “I can’t believe you were teasing me about the garter belt thing,” instead laughing. Huiwon looks unrepentant, grinning shark-like over her yuja tea. 
Huiwon smiles at him later, when she notices that he no longer has trouble looking Jonghyuk in the eye.
They don’t let him out of sight after that incident, but he finds he doesn’t mind.
 




The end of the novel is approaching.
 
 
There are so many things he has done to hurt them but as he reads he understands why he did so.
He blinks away tears he can’t explain at night, and hates and understands his future self in a way that aches.
If he looks too hard through the subway windows he can see himself sitting there, alone.
His fingers are smaller now, like they were when he spent probability like coins on Jonghyuk’s happiness.
 
 
The last few chapters before the epilogue have his heart in his throat. He’s been reading on the balcony, even though the wind is chilly beyond belief--his fingers went numb from the cold a while ago.
When he finds Sooyoung, she’s at the stove, snarking at Jihye’s cooking skills while Jihye herself watches, but they both turn to him with big grins when they hear his footsteps.
 
He feels bad--he’s about to ruin the mood.
“Do I look like him?” he asks, slow and uncertain. “The Most Ancient Dream?”
He thinks that’s why Jonghyuk may have avoided him in the beginning. He thinks that’s why Sangah and Hyungsung didn’t want to let go of him in the subway car.
Sooyoung takes in a deep breath. Jihye looks away from where she’s been watching them, leaning on the doorframe.
“You do,” Sooyoung says, tilting his face to get a better look at the bandage on his cheek. “Because you are Kim Dokja. But that does not mean you are one and the same. People grow, and there is no version of you we wouldn’t love.”
Jihye throws a coat on him and scowls, but bends down to help him with the buttons anyway when his half-frozen fingers refuse to cooperate.
 
 
Reader, dreamer. One and the same.
 
 
He’s going to finish tonight. He can feel how he’s almost whole again, just the last few cracks needing to be buffed over.
Dokja finds Jonghyuk and Sooyoung drinking tea at the table in silence. The kitchen is dimly lit—the sun has started going down already.
He opens his mouth to let them know he’s almost done, but Jonghyuk interrupts him.
“You’re almost done,” he says, voice solid as stone.
Sooyoung looks up from her tea.
Dokja nods, smiling slightly.
Sooyoung puts her cup down and pushes her chair back, standing up with a stretch before walking over to him.
“Well then,” she says. “I guess it’s goodbye to you. A short goodbye, though. You’ll see us again in your grown-up body.”
He’s glad she didn’t say “real” body. He’s plenty real here too.
She pulls him into a hug.
“You deserved better,” she says. “But we are here now. And we are not leaving.”
He hugs her back, and it feels less like a goodbye and more like a ‘see you later.’
Jonghyuk pats him on the head—a tad harshly, as if he’s not used to his strength—but Dokja smiles at it anyway.
The two of them (author and protagonist, author and protagonist, his mind whispers) start the process of getting everybody shuffling towards their beds. He’s relieved that they have the foresight to do so—he doesn’t want an audience when he finally finishes the story.
When he reaches the last chapter, he hugs Gilyoung and Yoosoung goodnight and waits until they (along with almost everyone else) are asleep, before heading to the living room.
“Goodnight, Dokja,” Sooyoung whispers, the last one awake, before closing the door. “See you on the other side.”
“Good night, Sooyoung noona,” he says, and then, “Thank you.” For everything. She smiles and leaves, and he’s alone.
He flips to the last few pages and stares.
 
He’s almost caught up.





(Dokja the  reader, doing what he was always meant to do.)





And he finishes the book. Every last chapter.
He rereads the last sentence.







 “This story is just for that one reader.” 





He loves Han Sooyoung so, so much. He loves all of them so much. 
He almost gets up to go find her, to yell at her for all her sacrifices (hypocritical, he knows) but finds he can’t find the energy to rise to his feet.
He feels tired, and he can’t quite keep his head up anymore. He manages to summon just enough energy to place the manuscript on the coffee table before the wave of fatigue overtakes him and he slumps over on the couch.
At some point during his impromptu nap, he feels himself being picked up and gathered in someone’s arms and they carry him a short distance before depositing him in an actual bed. He curls into it, and whoever it is chuckles and passes a hand through his hair before withdrawing. They seem to be talking to someone. With herculean effort, he pries his eyes open a bit.
He thinks he catches a glimpse of a small group of people. When he opens his eyes a sliver more, they seem to shine in the dim lighting of the room. He lingers on one of them in particular, who seems to have a tail and a golden circlet. They watch him for a moment, the strange people, then start to fade as they leave.
Dokja tries to keep his eyes open to watch them, but the overwhelming exhaustion proves to be too much, and his eyes start to slide closed again.
He hears the door click shut, and then nothing more.





In the morning,  Kim Dokja  wakes up.
 
 
The light filtering in through the blinds wakes him up, and he groans. 
When he sits up, he discovers that his body is suddenly much larger and that overnight the seams of the pajamas he’d been wearing had split. He makes a note to apologize to Gilyoung later, before abruptly realizing that he’s back in his real body, with every memory intact.
Sooyoung’s manuscript had really worked.
The memories of being that scared child are vague in his mind, the way he imagines the memories of being thirty were vague for his child-self. He can’t remember anything in much detail, except the overwhelming  love he’d felt for his family.
He sits up, trying to figure out what to do with the ruined pajamas and the fact that he’s nearly naked, when Jihye comes barreling into the room, throwing open the door.
“You’re going to be late for breakfast, you shrimp,” she’s yelling, “and how do you expect to grow taller without eating proper—“
She cuts herself off with a surprised scream.
“Dokja-ssi,” she gasps, once she processes what she’s looking at. And then to Dokja’s surprise, she bursts into tears and throws herself at him.
He manages to catch her in his arms, where she grips him with enough strength that he thinks he might bruise. She’s full-on sobbing, and he holds her tightly, rubbing a hand in circles on her back as she hiccups.
Eventually the rest of his family piles into the room, drawn by Jihye’s yelling in a panic, and they all stare once they realize what they’re looking at.
Hyungsung and Huiwon let out twins sighs of relief, while Jonghyuk raises an eyebrow and then leans on the doorframe to watch them all.
Sooyoung laughs when she sees him, as he frantically tries to cover his exposed skin with a blanket while simultaneously trying not to dislodge Jihye. 
Biyoo transforms with a faint  pop  and places herself on the crook of his neck with a faint  cheep noise. 
Yoosoung and Gilyoung follow Jihye’s lead and fail at holding back tears, though they tried valiantly to hold them in. They clamber on to him as well, like he’s a piece of playground equipment. An incredibly naked piece of playground equipment.
He sighs, but hugs them back all the same.
 
Huiwon takes the remains of Gilyoung’s pajamas and brings him some of his own clothes—a sweater that Sangah had knitted for his birthday one year, and some sweatpants Hyungsung had bought that turned out to be too small for him.
He changes into them after Sangah gets everyone out of the room, and then joins the rest of the family for breakfast at the table.
Hyungsung keeps passing him food as if on autopilot, and Dokja doesn’t say anything about it.
Jonghyuk’s made pancakes for breakfast, soft and fluffy, just the way Dokja likes them. 
He really isn’t subtle, is he?
After breakfast a couple of friends pop by—Jang Hayoung pouts when she realizes she’s no longer taller than him, Myungoh looks quietly relieved but also terrified of Sangah, and Gong Pildu slaps him on the back and tells him he’s still too skinny.
Aileen and Seolhwa both come by and poke at him until they determine that he’s healthy and there are no lingering after-effects. Aileen gives him a particularly intense glare and insists he tell them if anything feels even  slightly off. He nods yes, because he’s terrified of her.
(His mother comes by, once, and she holds him with trembling hands. She sits at the table with him, and Sangah hovers in the background after bringing them both tea. They talk, really  talk for the first time in a while. 
 
It doesn’t hurt.)
 
Nobody talks about the younger him, and the past that he doesn’t want to think about (standing on rooftops waiting for it to all end, wishing he was dead), and instead they all occupy his space like they’re afraid to leave him alone for more than a couple seconds at a time.
Again, all he can feel is the all encompassing love. His younger self had realized just how much they love him, too.
He thinks that whatever part of him that once became  The Most Ancient Dream  is finally, finally at rest.
 
 
Sangah, his first companion, his first friend—she catches him alone and shoos the rest of them out of the room, telling them she needs a minute with Dokja. They grumble, but acquise and leave.
Sangah sits him down and asks gently, “You’re happy here, aren’t you?”
Dokja blinks, surprised by the question. Of course it would be Sangah who asked. She knows how to read him better than anyone else.
“Of course,” he says, smiling. He wouldn’t trade this epilogue for the world.
She smiles back, bright as the sun.
 
 
At night, as they get ready for bed, he grins down at Sooyoung.
“I’m taller than you again,” he smirks, just to watch her temper flare.
She punches him in the shoulder, then sighs.
“I already miss the younger you. He was so polite.”
He rolls his eyes at her, and then to his alarm she bursts into tears for what must be the third time these past few weeks and throws her arms around him. She’s clutching at the fabric of his jacket so hard he thinks it might rip apart at the seams.
“Just fucking stay this time,” she hisses, “stay here and in one piece. I can’t take much more of this.”
He hugs her back just as tightly. (There’s a lot of people holding on to him for dear life today, aren’t there?)
“I’m not planning on going anywhere,” he says, pulling her close. “Not ever.”
 
Jonghyuk is laying on their shared futon already when he gets there, taking up most of the space.
“Jonghyuk-ah,” he says, almost petulantly.
Jonghyuk rolls his eyes but shifts so there’s enough space for the two of them, and Dokja lies down. Jonghyuk immediately moves into his space.
“How was it,” Dokja asks, “meeting the younger me?”
Jonghyuk states up at the ceiling. 
“Difficult,” he says. “Like most things are with you.”
Dokja knows well enough by now that the regressor means it fondly.
“I hope I didn’t cause much trouble,” he starts, unsure of what to say.
Jonghyuk sighs. “You worry too damn much. It was no trouble. It’s never any trouble with you.”
“Okay,” Dokja whispers, shifting under the covers. “Okay. Thank you.”
Jonghyuk holds him close, like he’s afraid he’ll disappear again, and he melts into the embrace, feeling the familiar fingers ghosting over his neck. 
Jonghyuk pulls back a little after a minute, and runs his thumb over Dokja’s cheekbone before kissing him, almost desperately. 
They fall asleep together, dreaming of an endless tomorrow.
